title: Monday, 13th August 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am

BornCynic Morning
BE11:08am

Anyway, let's catch up on the news in meantime.

BE11:08am

The Board of esure Group plc ("esure" or the "Company") notes the recent movement in its share price and confirms that, having received an unsolicited proposal from Bain Capital Private Equity, LP and its affiliates ("Bain Capital"), it is in the advanced stages of discussing a possible offer for the entire issued and to be issued share capital of the Company by Bain Capital.

Following discussions and a period of due diligence, Bain Capital has submitted a proposal to acquire all of the issued and to be issued shares of esure at 280 pence per share in cash (the "Proposal").

The Proposal represents:

· a premium of approximately 37 per cent. to the closing share price of 204 pence on 10 August 2018 (being the last business day prior to this Announcement);

· a premium of approximately 40 per cent. to the one month volume weighted average price of 199 pence per esure Share to 10 August 2018; and

· a premium of approximately 29 per cent. to the three month volume weighted average price of 216 pence per esure Share to 10 August 2018.

The Board of esure has indicated to Bain Capital that it would be minded to recommend a firm offer for esure if made by Bain Capital at the price set out in the Proposal, subject to the agreement of terms relating to the Proposal.

Kiwi-juice @Excel: all the Turks are selling their gold to convert to Lira, haven't you heard the suggestions of dear calife Erdogan?

Forester Looking for short break to Bodrum in half term - package prices are pre-crisis so will book late & direct!

.... second thoughts, quick scan of the Monday strategy notes are a bit dull. Let's do banks instead.

HSBC Holdings PLC (HSBA:LSE): Last: 716.90, down 4.4 (-0.61%), High: 722.70, Low: 716.40, Volume: 6.41m
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 672.00, down 7.9 (-1.16%), High: 678.00, Low: 671.90, Volume: 1.66m
11:23 am
BE11:24am

No big whoop, says JP Morgan.

BE11:24am

Based on company disclosure, Turkey contributed
0.4% of HSBC’s loan book and less than 1.6% of pre-tax profits in 2017. Contribution from STAN’s Turkish
subsidiary to group’s assets and net income is close to zero. Nonetheless of actual exposures, with market
starting to price in higher risk of further turbulence in emerging markets (EM), other EM currencies will start to
see pressure, and this is likely to weigh on the share performance of STAN, which is being viewed as an EM
bank. As such, we prefer HSBC over STAN at this environment.

BE11:25am

There's a Turkish Banks "ranked by total assets" table -- I'll share the top 20.

Penny @wayne - v good question
11:25 am
BE11:25am

BE11:26am

BE11:26am

And here's Morgan Stanley for the wider European view.

wayneJ @Penny - and I also wonder if there is a difference in the accounting - no idea but just curious. Not sure I would accuse Sir Peter Wood of being overly extravagant nor of not knowing what he is doing....
11:26 am
BE11:27am

Our estimates suggests minimal exposures to Turkey outside of BBVA, UCG, BNP and ING: Assessment of financial disclosure suggests limited exposure to Turkey beyond these four banks although we recognise that disclosure may not be exhaustive. The loan book exposures amount to ~2-3% of total group for ING (via ING Bank Turkey SA) and BNP (via its 72.5% ownership in TEB), ~4% at Unicredit (40.9% owner of Yapi Kredi) and ~13% at BBVA (49.9% owner of Garanti), with modest further Sovereign exposures also reported.

BE11:27am

Equity exposures from Turkish subsidiaries range from 2-11% across the 4 banks: Based on end 2017 reported financials, the total equity of Turkish subsidiaries/associates accounts for ~2% of group CET1 at ING and BNP, ~6% at Unicredit and ~11% at BBVA. As we discuss below we recognise that this could understate for parent company support of the subsidiaries given potential additional intergroup funding lines.

BE11:28am

And another nearly invisible table .....

11:28 am
BE11:28am

wayneJ Would have thought a bank treasury dept / risk management team worth its salt would have hedges in place for non-base currencies....but then my faith may be naively placed.
BE11:28am

Right-click, open in new tab. Yeah, I know. We don't have click to enlarge. Same reason search doesn't work.

11:29 am
Ashmore Group PLC (ASHM:LSE): Last: 338.40, down 18.6 (-5.21%), High: 356.80, Low: 335.00, Volume: 1.63m
BE11:30am

We can partly blame Turkey there, as while it's unlikely to be much of Ashmore's portfolio -- 2-3% maybe -- it's going to sour sentiment to EM debt generally.

BE11:31am

The better reason Ashmore's down is this, from Numis.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

We are becoming increasingly concerned on Ashmore's short-medium term outlook, albeit on a long term basis and we still consider the shares to be trading around fair value. In particular, we believe it is becoming increasingly unlikely that the company will meet consensus expectations for flows (consensus: FY19: + $8.0bn/11% of opening AuM, FY20: +$7.7bn/8%), should investor sentiment towards EM remain under pressure (our flow forecasts FY19: +$2.0bn, FY20: +$0.8bn). We think the flow outlook for the next quarter or two will likely remain fine, given the time lag between weakening sentiment and institutional clients making decisions, however, we think the risk of a large consensus downgrade to flows and/or a large quarterly flow miss in the next 6-12 months is building. We retain our hold recommendation for now given the immediate outlook and lower share price, but this remains very much under close review.

wayneJ @Mouselet - never put on a hedge when you need it; always put it on when you don't.....
BE11:33am

In terms of the mobile operators .......

Mouselet So if I believe that Erdogan is meaningfully different from Abiy Ahmed or Moon Jae-in then I should buy EM index trackers; if I had EM funds rather than index trackers then I should sell them and leave the money in cash if the manager had still a substantial position in Turkey over the weekend
wayneJ There is a longer conversation to be had about the US using the USD as a weapon ie sanctions vs Russia, Turkey , Iran, N Korea etc and what the implications are for trust and confidence in the US dollar outside of the USA. In the short term it shows the USD is supreme - in the longer term what are the implications of the Petro-Yuan etc.

11:34 am

BE11:35am

Turkcell comprises c5% of Telia’s equity and also c6-7% of Telia's EFCF in 2018-19. Our (and also likely consensus) current estimates are already updated for 2Q numbers – which include some of the weakness in the Lira YTD. If we were to update our estimates to spot, we would cut our valuation by c1.5% and our EFCF by c2%. In conclusion, while the Lira moves are not entirely
negligible for Telia, they do not change our bullish conviction on the stock for H2. As a reminder, we are 10-
16% above company consensus OpFC (organic ex M&A) for 2018-2020; the Lira related cut is therefore
relatively modest in this respect.

But there are 3500 other cases out there like this one, and theyll probably end up using the same legal strategy. Will be interesting to see what sort of final number they settle at

Soundbuy Interesting read re RoundUp http://ecofarmingdaily.com/glyphosate-a-toxic-legacy/?jVvN1

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Which was marketed as Roundup and might or might not cause cancer

comm_1100 the EU just renewed glyphosate's license for 5 years last year, so I don't think (famous last words) that they'll turn around and ban it
BE11:44am

Here's Citi.

BE11:45am

This is the first lawsuit to go to trial alleging a link between glyphosate and cancer (estimated 450 cases California and 4-5,000 nationally by US attorneys). For reference US agencies EPA and NIH have taken the stance glyphosate does not cause cancer. In November 2017 the EU Commission's Appeal Committee voted 18-9 to renew the glyphosate license for 5 years, though France continues to agitate for a ban. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has stated glyphosate is unlikely to cause cancer. While Roundup sales are not disclosed it makes up the majority of reported Agricultural Productivity sales at Monsanto (FY17 sales $3.7bn).

Excel Developer @Kiwi: I think Obama, Clinton would have handled it differently (better).
comm_1100 but if you're Bayer, and you're trying to position yourself as a sort of family friendly Pharma company, this doesn't look great
11:45 am
BE11:45am

So ...........

BE11:45am

Bulls will argue the ruling against Monsanto can be appealed, that eventual damages will likely be significantly reduced, and that WHO’s IARC in 2015 incorrectly classified glyphosate as a “probable carcinogen”, which US patent attorneys have used opportunistically. Monsanto will point to a “raft of scientific evidence” (800 studies) pointing to glyphosate being non-carcinogenic. Bears will point to the potential for multi-billion dollar litigation costs and extrapolate the weekend’s ruling across outstanding cases.

FJ Bayer goodwill impairment?
BE11:46am

Citi's conclusion here is, "don't buy embattled companies," which feels a bit lazy rather than entirely wrong.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Over the past year our thesis has become more
underpinned by valuation arguments given the issues facing Pharma (Xarelto patent cliff, poor pipeline perception, and FDA warning letter related to Leverkusen plant), Consumer (tough market backdrop compounded by Merck Consumer acquisition and problems with Coppertone and Dr Scholl’s), and Crop Science (Brazil inventory issues and depressed Ag Cycle). News over the weekend makes it near impossible to credibly remain Buyers of the stock, given the unquantifiable overhang created, and we downgrade to Neutral. While our PE, DCF and SOTP valuations range from €120-132, we now apply a 25-30% discount to account for glyphosate litigation risks following the recent adverse ruling in California and cut our TP to €93, from €132.

BE11:47am

HSBC also on hold.

BE11:48am

In our view, investors need not panic, but: (1) optically, a near-USD300m award in a single Roundup case only a few months after completing a USD60bn+ acquisition may not make the deal look either well timed or smart; Bayer will have to justify what due diligence it has conducted on Roundup and any potential financial liability. Investors should look at the level (or lack) of contingent liabilities at the Q2 results on 5 September; (2) that aside, investors should expect further headlines on similar litigation, none of which would likely be helpful for Bayer’s share price performance due to the uncertainty they would create, especially if investors were to act before waiting for answers.

wayneJ 'WHO’s IARC in 2015 incorrectly classified glyphosate as a “probable carcinogen”, ' ----hmmmm......just like my teachers incorrectly marked my exam papers.....
Swedish Chef "embattled companies?" I bought BP straight after Deepwater. at c360 I recall.
11:48 am
BE11:48am

And Cazenove buying the dip.

BE11:49am

(Not glyphosate dip. I mean the share price dip.)

BE11:49am

We see today’s -11% move as significantly overdone and see this as a very good long-term buying opportunity

wayneJ Bayer's market cap seems to be rapidly negating the entire value of the Monsanto acquisition....
11:49 am
BE11:50am

They link to "Revised Glyphosate Issue Paper:
Evaluation of Carcinogenic Potential
EPA’s Office of Pesticide Programs
December 12, 2017"

BE11:50am

Which is a pretty decent looking metastudy of "63 epidemiological studies, 14 animal carcinogenicity studies and c90 genotoxicity studies, concluding that the data available at this time do not support carcinogenicity of glyphosate."

BE11:51am

Overall, this review clearly supports
the lack of carcinogenicity link for glyphosate and even though there is uncertainty over NHL cases,
lack of data does not constitute guilt, in our view, hence we believe Bayer-Monsanto has a good chance
of overturning this result on appeal.

comm_1100 @FJ don't think you'll see an impairment for a while. Monsanto is frequently subject to lawsuits and I think when this case is over the settlement figure will be one of those "unusual/infrequent items". You can argue of course it really is that unusual if you're getting sued all the time but I digress..
wayneJ This does open an interesting line of attack for the anti-GMO groups - don't attack the GMO per se but rather the chemicals that the GMOs are resistant to; and the attack is focussed not on the impact on the population as a whole or the impact on wildlife but those who administer the chemicals ie farming staff etc....
11:51 am
BE11:51am

So ... bet on the jury award being overturned or significantly reduced, JPM says.

BE11:52am

This particular patient, a 46-year old groundskeeper at a school in San Francisco, had
developed Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma a type of blood cancer. While NHL is associated with advanced age
(c60-65), c12% of NHL patients in the US are in the 45-54 age bracket, and therefore, we believe Bayer-
Monsanto stands a good chance of overturning the case on appeal and we believe that, at least, the $289m in
damages could be substantially reduced.

BE11:53am

Very unlikely that glyphosate will be removed from the market: We estimate Round-up represents c4% of
Bayer EBITDA related to the herbicide sales in Monsanto’s Agricultural productivity line. However, we do
not see this being at risk, given a recent positive vote in the EU to relicense glyphosate and positive opinion
on the product from the US EPA, which we believe has considered the full picture of evidence around the
product and has found it to be safe. We already expect sales of glyphosate to decline over time as the product
is replaced by new technologies (such as Dicamba), which have a higher prices.

wayneJ Also metastudies are notoriously 'soft' evidence unless conducted very carefully.
Swedish Chef Perhaps juries ought to undergo a course in statistical significance before being sworn in?
11:54 am
undefined
wayneJ Question - if you are an employer eg a farmer or a state park etc can you now afford to use RoundUp or will you have joint and several liability with the manufacturer? Will you be insureable?
BE11:55am

Hmmmmmmm ... Direct Line and Admiral up on the Esure news ..............

Direct Line Insurance Group PLC (DLG:LSE): Last: 329.50, up 7 (+2.17%), High: 330.70, Low: 321.00, Volume: 3.19m
11:55 am
Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 2,016, up 29 (+1.46%), High: 2,019, Low: 1,974, Volume: 228.78k
Hastings Group Holdings PLC (HSTG:LSE): Last: 259.80, up 9.8 (+3.92%), High: 263.60, Low: 245.80, Volume: 366.57k

BE11:57am

What's the thought process here? Further consolidation? Or is it just having the market share taker owned by Bain?

Swedish Chef Wayne - if you use a product that is fully EU approved for the application and you abide by PPE etc I don't see how an English judge would find you negligent.
Excel Developer GBPUSD has a 1.27 handle, haha
11:58 am
BE11:58am

Have some RBC ......

BE11:58am

The proposal of 280p is just ahead of our 275p price target, which we base on 11.8x our 2019E profit forecast. Although the offer still represents an undemanding multiple (12.2x our 2019E EPS forecast), given the backdrop
in the UK motor market with softening prices plus a motivated seller of more than 30% of the stock, we believe this offer probably represents the best that esure can expect for now until the cycle turns. Although esure traded as high as 288p just a year ago, the mood around UK motor insurance stocks has become far more negative in recent months as pricing begins to soften

wayneJ @Swedish Chef - I was thinking about the US. If you are an employer involved in crops etc and your staff are exposed to RoundUp will you be insured henceforth?
BE11:59am

We expect that other private equity firms plus a number of trade players will have considered making an offer, but we do not expect a counter offer to emerge. To us, there is limited read-across to the other UK motor insurers as this situation involves a motivated seller, a circumstance which we do not see at the other UK motor insurers.

Excel Developer @waynej: doubtful, US medical insurance (at least used to ) runs a mile away from those with prior medical conditions.
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Hm .... there were of course ideas about Admiral's Engelhardt being a potential seller several years ago ....

BE12:00pm

........... though they came to nothing.

undefined

Close out with bloody House of Fraser? I guess we should.

Debenhams PLC (DEB:LSE): Last: 12.27, up 0.6296 (+5.41%), High: 12.30, Low: 11.28, Volume: 4.08m
wayneJ @XL - I meant employers liability insurance; what will be your defence if one of your employees develops cancer and his role involves handling Roundup after this case?
Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 399.50, down 5.9 (-1.46%), High: 407.40, Low: 398.10, Volume: 180.22k
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Why on earth is Debenhams up?

BE12:02pm

Is the idea that Ashley maneuvers HoF and Debenhams into some kind of shotgun marriage?

BE12:03pm

Because, hell's teeth.

wayneJ Daily Mail says 'Michael Murray' the 'so-called "head of elecation"' will be running House of Fraser.....hmmmm
Excel Developer @waynej: yeah, yeah, understood, strongly correlated.
wayneJ (Whoops - meant head of elevation)
12:03 pm
BE12:04pm

Quick line from Stifel.

BE12:04pm

The [£90m] transaction implies a 6x P/E multiple,
according to our estimates. Mike Ashley, with an 11% stake in HoF, was one of the
contenders for the company, in addition to Philip Day, Chinese C.Banner and Cenbest.
Debenhams' shares (Sports Direct owns a 29.7% stake) were up 3% this morning as
House of Fraser's administration appeared final: while short-term pain was expected on
the back of HoF's inventory clearance, it would have increased demand for Debenhams
and John Lewis over Christmas trading, the most important trading period of the year.
Both companies are due to report their results on 13 September and 25 October.

BE12:05pm

And from Nick Bubb ........

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Although the brief statement from Mike Ashley on Friday lunchtime about the acquisition of the House of Fraser business from the administrators said that “Our deal was conservative, consistent and simple” it looks nothing of the sort and it is far from clear if he really knows what he has taken on (having had his 11% equity stake wiped out). Our first reaction was that £90m was quite a lot to pay for the business, even debt-free, given that it is heading for a loss of over £50m on gross sales of c£1.1bn this year (albeit first-half weighted) and restructuring will cost a lot of money, and that it reminded us of the ill-fated acquisition of a sports business in Austria by Sports Direct five years ago that turned into a disaster…Despite the claim that “We will do our best to keep as many stores open as possible” we suspect that he will end up selling on a handful of the best stores to John Lewis/Selfridges and dump the worst stores with the likes of Philip Day and try to keep the rump as an upmarket trophy to show off to Nike and Adidas…

wayneJ (What does Head of Elevation mean anyway?)
Lemmy he's in charge of the lifts and escalators?
BE12:06pm

............ Selfridges? Hm. I could see Selfridges being interested in a store like Jenners in Edinburgh -- apart from the fact that Selfridges already has a bloody great custom build five minutes up the road.

BE12:07pm

Liberum also.

Excel Developer #Elevation Someone who puts their feet up.
12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

At first glance, SPD’s acquisition of HoF could prove to be a shrewd strategic move. At the recent prelims, SPD management clearly highlighted its intentions to align its wider apparel credentials with its significant relationships in footwear to develop a broader offer that strengthens appeal across the UK fashion market. This forms part of a top-down strategy, through the group’s Premium Lifestyle and Sport Retail divisions, which flows from luxury (Flannels), down to premium (Cruise, van mildert) and to mass-market (USC, Sports Direct), as well the group’s more nascent discount designer outlet stores (Brand Max).

HoF’s business, including its strong strategic relationships for which it has become so well know, can broaden SPD’s brand relationships and make it a more significant player across all areas of the UK clothing market. It includes some very attractive store locations which can support SPD’s multi-channel “Elevation Strategy”. A central strand to this has been the rolling out of a new generation of stores, including flagships that average c. 40,000 sq. ft. and are of a scale and location that allows the group to showcase the best products from both third parties and its own brands. Importantly, the benefits could flow both ways with House of Fraser benefitting from SPD’s broad relationships, including its more fashion focused offerings (Flannels, Cruise, van mildert). In a broader context, we believe this rescue deal should not only be seen positively in terms of saving jobs and helpful for the future of the high street, but also the fact that HoF is a business on which many smaller and dynamic fashion brands rely.

BE12:08pm

For Debs, bad news, they say.

BE12:08pm

The shape of the future HoF business remains uncertain, but the rescue deal, supported by SPD’s balance sheet and strong management team, is likely to steady the ship over time and secure a more sustainable growth platform. This is a potential negative for Debenhams (DEB), where we expect the management team will be less pleased now that Mike Ashley has become a direct competitor.

SPD has stated that it will do it’s best to keep as many HoF stores open as possible. Given its ambitions across the wider UK clothing sector, we see this as a challenge not only for DEB, but also potentially the likes of M&S and Next within the department store space. In the event some HoF stores are closed, and to the extent this leads to discounting to clear stock, this could also have negative short-term repercussions for rivals, which could include during the run up to the key Christmas period. We see the news as an overall incremental positive for Ted Baker (BUY, TP £33), which we understand to generate c.2-3% of its group sales through HoF’s business.

12:08 pm
Ted Baker PLC (TED:LSE): Last: 2,168, down 10.1 (-0.46%), High: 2,182, Low: 2,166, Volume: 15.36k
undefined
BE12:09pm

That'll do, right? That's plenty for a Monday.

wayneJ So the strategy is 'might', 'could', 'should', 'would'.....
12:09 pm
BE12:10pm

Back tomorrow, I guess.

Excel Developer cheers bye
wayneJ @BE - welcome back by the way....
BE12:10pm

And ta for the comments, I guess.

BE12:10pm

Afternoon all.

nut cracker Cheers
